The '''Civil Services''' refer to the [[civil service|civil services]], the permanent [[Executive (government)|executive branch]] of the [[Republic of India]]. The civil service system is the backbone of the administrative machinery of the country.<ref name="Civil Service System">{{cite web |url=http://arc.gov.in/viet.ppt |title=The civil service system |author=Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances|date=8 June 2011 |work= |publisher=Government of India |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=11 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="India National Civil Service">{{cite web |url=http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/APCITY/unpan006306.pdf |title=National Civil Service System in India : A Critical View|author=[[United Nations Public Administration Network]]|date= |work= |publisher=Government of India |location= |accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref>
In the [[Parliamentary system|parliamentary democracy]] of India, the [[Ultimate (sport)|ultimate]] responsibility for running the administration rests with the elected representatives of the people which are the ministers. But the handful of ministers cannot be expected to deal personally with the manifold problems of modern administration. Thus the ministers lay down the policy and it is for the civil servants to carry out this policy.
The [[Executive (government)|executive]] decisions are implemented by the Indian civil servants. The members of civil service serve at the pleasure of the [[President of India]] and Article 311 of the [[Constitution of India|constitution]] protects them from politically motivated or vindictive action. Civil servants are employees of the [[Government of India]]; however, not all employees of the Government are civil servants. Civil servants in a personal capacity are paid from the [[Civil List]]. Senior civil servants may be called to account by [[Parliament of India|Parliament]].
As of year 2010, there are total 6.4 million government employees in India, and less than 50,000 civil servants to administer them.<ref name="CS Report">{{cite web |url=http://darpg.gov.in/darpgwebsite_cms/Document/file/Civil_Services_Survey_2010.pdf|title=The year 2010 Civil Services Report: A Survey|author=[[Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions (India)|Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions]], Department of Administrative Reforms and Public Grievances|date=8 June 2010 |work= |publisher=Government of India |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=10 February 2012}}</ref> The civil service system in India is rank-based and does not follow the tenets of the position-based civil services.<ref name="India National Civil Service"/>
In October 2015, the [[Government of India]] approved the formation of "new" Indian Skill Development Service-Group A.<ref name="Group A creation">{{cite web|title=Government nod to raise new Group-A civil service cadre|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/XO89PxfcsCgWQ31vyFi6cJ/Government-nod-to-raise-new-GroupA-civil-service-cadre.html|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="ISDS-India">{{cite web|title=Govt approves formation of Indian Skill Development Service|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/govt-approves-formation-of-indian-skill-development-service/articleshow/49261963.cms|accessdate=8 October 2015}}</ref>
==History== Lord [[Warren Hastings]] laid the foundations of civil service and [[Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis|Charles Cornwallis]] reformed, modernised and rationalised it. Hence, [[Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis|Charles Cornwallis]] is known as the 'Father of Civil Service in India'. He introduced Covenanted Civil Services (higher civil services) and Uncovenanted Civil Services (lower civil services).
The present civil services of India is mainly based on the pattern of the former [[Indian Civil Service (British India)|Indian Civil Service]] of [[British India]]. The civil services were divided into two categories - covenanted and uncovenanted. The covenanted civil service consisted of only Europeans (i.e., English personnel) occupying the higher posts in the government. The uncovenanted civil service was solely introduced to facilitate the entry of Indians at the lower rung of the administration.<ref>Meghna Sabharwal, Evan M. Berman "Public Administration in South Asia: India, Bangladesh, and Pakistan (Public Administration and Public Policy," (2013)</ref><ref name="CUC Civil Service">{{cite web |url=http://www.bl.uk/reshelp/findhelpregion/asia/india/indiaofficerecordsfamilyhistory/occupations/civilservice/civilservice.html |title=Civil Service |author=|date=8 June 2011 |work= |publisher=The British Library|location= |accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref>
With the passing of the [[Government of India Act 1919]], the [[Indian Civil Service (British India)|Imperial Services]] headed by the [[Secretary of State for India]], were split into two – [[All India Services]] and [[Central Civil Services of India|Central Services]].<ref name="Public Personnel Administration">{{cite book| title =Public Personnel Administration : Theory and Practice||last=Goel |first=S.L. | publisher=Deep and Deep Publications, 2008| isbn = 9788176293952}}</ref>
The [[All India Services|All India]] and class 1 [[Central Civil Services of India|Central Services]] were designated as Central Superior Services as early as 1924.<ref name="Problems and Issues Administration">{{cite book| title =Problems and Issues in Administrative Federalism||last=Maheshwari |first=Shriram | publisher=Allied Publishers| isbn = 9788170233428}}</ref> From 1924 to 1934, Administration in India consisted of "nine<ref name="Problems and Issues Administration"/> to seven" All India Services and five central departments, all under the control of Secretary of State for India, and 3 central departments under joint Provincial and Imperial Control.
===Present day=== The present modern civil service was formed after the [[partition of India]] in 1947. It was [[Sardar Patel]]'s vision that the Civil Service should strengthen cohesion and national unity. The values of integrity, impartiality and merit remain the guiding principles of Indian civil services.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
Since the early 20th century, Indian civil servants have been colloquially called "[[Babu (title)|babus]]",<ref>{{cite web| title = Yet to start work, Natgrid CEO highest paid babu| url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Yet-to-start-work-Natgrid-CEO-highest-paid-babu/articleshow/15610191.cms?referral=PM |date=Aug 23, 2012| accessdate = 2014-09-17 | publisher = The Times of India}}</ref> while Indian bureaucracy is called "babudom", as in the "rule of babus", especially in Indian media.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/fline/fl1818/18181170.htm |title=A barbed look at babudom: Will the typically British humour of Yes Minister work if transplanted to an Indian setting? Viewers of a Hindi satellite channel have a chance to find out. |date=Sep 1–14, 2001 |author=Anand Parthasarathy |publisher=[[Frontline (magazine)|Frontline]], India's National Magazine from the publishers of ''The Hindu'' |quote=Bureaucracy knows no bounds... }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = PM Modi tightens screws, gives babudom a new rush hour | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/PM-Modi-tightens-screws-gives-babudom-a-new-rush-hour/articleshow/41482792.cms |date=Sep 2, 2014| accessdate = 2014-09-17 | publisher = The Times of India}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = Babu|work=Collins English Dictionary| url = http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/babudom | accessdate = 2014-09-17 }}</ref>
==Constitution== The [[Constitution of India|constitution]] under Article 312<ref>{{cite web|title=Constitution of India, Article 312|url=http://indiankanoon.org/doc/647227/}}</ref> provides for All India Civil Services branches to be set up by giving the power to the [[Rajya Sabha]] (upper house of the Parliament of India) to resolve by a two-thirds majority to establish new all-India services. The [[Indian Administrative Service]], [[Indian Police Service]] and [[Indian Forest Service]] are set up under this constitutional provision.<ref>{{cite web|title=Official Government website|url=http://www.archive.india.gov.in/knowindia/profile.php?id=32}}</ref>
==Power, purpose and responsibilities== [[File:Passports_Front.jpg|thumb|An Indian diplomatic passport and an official passport which is generally issued to civil servants. As opposed to the deep blue passport issued to ordinary Indian citizens, the diplomatic passport is [[maroon]] coloured with the golden text 'Diplomatic Passport' printed on it, and the [[Hindi]] equivalent.]] The responsibility of the civil services is to run the administration of India. The country is managed through a number of Central Government agencies in accordance with the policy directions given by the ministries.
The members of the civil services represent as administrators in the central government and state government; emissaries in the foreign missions/embassies; as tax collectors and revenue commissioners; as civil service commissioned police officers; as permanent representative(s) and employees in the [[United Nations]] and its agencies and as Chairman, Managing Director, full-time functional Director/Member of the Board of Management of various Public Sector Undertakings/ Enterprises, Corporations, Banks and financial institutions. Civil servants are employed to [[List of Indian agencies|various agencies of India]] and can also be appointed as advisors or [[Officer on Special Duty (India)|special duty officers]] or [[Private Secretary|private secretaries]] to ministers of the Union and the State Government.<ref name="Staff Minister Rules">{{cite web|title=Consolidated Instructions to the appointment of personal staff to Union Ministers|url=http://ccis.nic.in/WriteReadData/CircularPortal/D2/D02csd/uploading.pdf|publisher=[[Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions]]|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref><ref name="Staff Minister">{{cite web|title=Why babus want to be private secys to ministers now|url=http://www.governancenow.com/news/regular-story/why-babus-want-be-private-secys-ministers-now|publisher=GovernanceNow.com|accessdate=16 May 2015}}</ref>
All appointments in the rank of [[Joint Secretary to Government of India]] and above, other major appointments, empanelment and extension of tenure is done by the [[Appointments Committee of the Cabinet (India)|Appointments Committee of the Cabinet]]. However, all appointments in the rank below Joint Secretary in the federal government is done by the [[Civil Services Board (India)|Civil Services Board]].
==Governance== ===Head of the Civil Service=== <!-- This section is linked from [[Cabinet Secretary]] as well as a number of other pages --> The highest ranking civil servant is the [[Cabinet Secretary (India)|Cabinet Secretary]]. He is [[ex-officio]] Chairman of the [[Civil Services Board (India)|Civil Services Board]]; the chief of the Indian Administrative Service and head of all civil services under the rules of business of the [[Government of India]]. He also holds the 11th position in the [[Indian order of precedence|Order of Precedence of India]].
The position holder is accountable for ensuring that the Civil Service is equipped with the skills and capability to meet the everyday challenges it faces and that civil servants work in a fair and decent environment.

==Values and codes==
===Values=== A member of the civil service in discharge of his/her functions is to be guided by maintaining absolute integrity, allegiance to the constitution and the law of the nation, patriotism, national pride, devotion to duty, honesty, impartiality and transparency.<ref name="valuecodes">{{Cite web|url=http://www.upacademy.org/presentationpdf/-%20Civil_Services_in_Idia_UPAAM.pdf|title=The Role of civil services in India (Standard Note: DOPT/Government of India)|last=Misra|first=P.K.|date=4 August 2010|publisher=Department of Personnel and Training, Government of India|accessdate=2011-08-27}}</ref>
===Codes=== The Government of India promotes values and a certain standard of ethics of requiring and facilitating every civil servant:<ref name="valuecodes"/> * To discharge official duty with responsibility, honesty, accountability and without discrimination. * To ensure effective management, leadership development and personal growth. * To avoid misuse of official position or information. * To serve as instruments of good governance and foster social economic development.
==Construction== The Civil Services of India can be classified into two types - the [[All India Services]] and the [[Central Civil Services of India|Central Civil Services]] (Group A and B). The recruits are university graduates (or above) selected through a rigorous system of examinations, called the [[Civil Services Examination]] (CSE) and the [[Engineering Services Examination]] (ESE) conducted by the [[Union Public Service Commission]] (UPSC) and the Combined Graduate Level Examination (CGLE) by the <ref>Staff Selection Commission</ref> (SSC).
===All India Civil Services (AIS)=== All appointments to [[All India Services|All India Civil Services]] are made by the [[President of India]]. * [[Indian Administrative Service]] (IAS) * [[Indian Forest Service]] (IFoS)<ref>{{cite web|title=Inclusion of IFS in Civil Services India|url=http://www.civilserviceindia.com/India-Foreign-Service.html}}</ref> * [[Indian Police Service]] (IPS)

==Reforms and corruption== {{Main|Civil service reform in developing countries}} As of 2011, in a duration of past three years over 450 [[chargesheet]]s have been filed and a total of 943 cases are at different stages of investigation by [[Central Bureau of Investigation|CBI]] against civil servants.<ref name="Corruption civil service">{{cite web |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/453-ias-ips-and-civil-servants-charge-sheeted-in-last-3-yrs/879559/ |title=453 IAS,and other civil servants chargesheeted in last 3 yrs |date=23 November 2011 |work= |publisher=Indian Express |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=27 November 2011}}</ref><ref name="corruption service">{{cite web |url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/nation/over-400-central-officers-booked-in-last-3-yrs_743388.html |title=Over 400 central officers booked in last 3 yrs |date=23 November 2011 |work= |publisher=Zee News |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=27 November 2011}}</ref>

On 28 November 2011, the Department of Personnel and Training (DOPT) of the [[Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions (India)|Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions]] created a proposal to retire and remove incompetent, inefficient and unproductive [[All India Service]] officers after 15 years of service, instead of tolerating them until their retirement. Former [[Cabinet Secretary (India)|Cabinet Secretary]] [[TSR Subramanian]] welcomed this move with caution, saying, "Periodical weeding out is very good. But the process to determine who needs to be prematurely retired should be fair and transparent. There is a possibility that even good officers may be targeted because of political reasons,". Former [[Union Public Service Commission|UPSC]] chairman PC Hota echoed his sentiments remarking that, "We need drastic remedies. The situation has become terrible. The other day an officer in Delhi was arrested for disproportionate assets of Rs.31.5 million. She is just a 2000-batch [[Indian Administrative Service]] (IAS) officer with 11 years of service. But at the same time, the officers' service records should be analysed before a decision against him was taken".<ref name="AIS lazy retire">{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/lazy-and-incompetent-babus-to-retire-early/1/162137.html |title=Lazy and incompetent babus of the All India Services to retire early|date=30 November 2011 |work= |publisher=[[India Today]] |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=9 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="corruption compulsory retirement">{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/graft-taint-may-lead-to-retirement-for-babus/1/179684.html |title=Corruption taint may lead to compulsory retirement for babus|date=21 April 2012 |work= |publisher=[[India Today]] |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=21 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="AIS retire 15 incompetence">{{cite web |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/report/proposal-to-retire-incompetent-officers-after-15-year-service/20111130.htm |title=Proposal to retire incompetent officers after 15-year service|date=30 November 2011 |work= |publisher=Rediff News |location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=3 February 2012}}</ref> The proposal has been accepted and rule 16(3) of the All India Services (death-cum-retirement benefits) Rules of 1958 was amended on 31 January 2012.<ref name="AIS lazy retire"/><ref name="AIS retire 15 incompetence"/><ref name="Govt of India notification for amending Rule 16(3) of the All India Service (DCRB) Rules, 1958">{{cite web|title=Govt of India notification for amending Rule 16(3) of the All India Service (DCRB) Rules, 1958|url=http://circulars.nic.in/WriteReadData/CircularPortal/D2/D02ser/25013_02_2005-AIS-II-31012012.pdf|publisher=Govt of India|accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref>
{{Quote box |quote = "Much of the deterioration in the functioning of bureaucracy is due to political interference." |source = Justice [[KS Radhakrishnan]] and Justice [[PC Ghose]], [[Supreme Court of India]]<ref name="TSR Subramanian case"/> |width = 20% }}
In October 2013, the [[Supreme Court of India]], in the case of ''[[TSR Subramanian|TSR Subramanian & Ors vs Union of India & Ors]]'' <ref name="WRIT PETITION (CIVIL) NO(s). 82 OF 2011">{{cite web|title=WRIT PETITION (CIVIL) NO(s). 82 OF 2011|url=http://courtnic.nic.in/supremecourt/temp/wc%208211p.txt|accessdate=31 October 2013}}</ref> ordered both [[Government of India]] and [[State governments of India|State governments]] to ensure fixed tenure to civil servants. The court asked senior bureaucrats to write down the oral instructions from politicians so that a record would be kept of all the decisions. This judgement was seen on the similar lines of the Supreme Court's 2006 judgement in [[Prakash Singh case]] on [[Indian police reforms|police reforms]].<ref name="Prakash Singh Case">{{cite web|title=Prakash Singh Case|url=http://www.indiankanoon.org/doc/1090328/|accessdate=12 April 2013}}</ref><ref name="SC asks states to file affidavit on police reforms">{{cite news|title=SC asks states to file affidavit on police reforms|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/SC-asks-states-to-file-affidavit-on-police-reforms/Article1-945679.aspx|accessdate=16 October 2012|newspaper=Hindustan Times|date=16 October 2012}}</ref> The judgement was welcomed by various bureaucrats and [[Media of India|the media]] who hoped that it will help in giving freedom and independence to the functioning of bureaucracy.<ref name="TSR Subramanian case">{{cite news|title=Supreme Court favours law to regulate transfer, posting of IAS officers|url=http://www.niticentral.com/2013/10/31/sc-favours-law-to-regulate-transfer-posting-of-ias-officers-152923.html|accessdate=31 October 2013|date=31 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="T S R Subramanian case">{{cite news|title=SC to bureaucrats: Don't take oral instructions from netas|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/SC-to-bureaucrats-Dont-take-oral-instructions-from-netas/articleshow/24978551.cms|accessdate=31 October 2013|date=31 October 2013|work=The Times Of India}}</ref>
To recruit better candidates for the various services, UPSC brought about changes in the Prelims stage of the Civil Services Examination in 2011 by abolishing the optional subject paper and introducing the Civil Services Aptitude Test (CSAT). Further changes were made in the Mains stage of the exam from 2013 onwards. Despite recent revisions, the contents of the exam are still same and the quality of the candidates is dropping day by day. It requires lot of cramming power to succeed in this exam. Since, only people with no opportunities in private sector, get the time and the patience to prepare for 2-3 years for civil services, the quality of the candidates have really become very low, as the better candidates go for MBA or offshore assignments in IT companies to US.
In 2016, the [[Ministry of Finance (India)|Ministry of Finance]] for the first time, dismissed 72 and prematurely retired another 33 [[Indian Revenue Service]] officers for non-performance and on disciplinary grounds.<ref name="Finance Ministry 2016">{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/for-good-governance-finance-ministry-fires-72-tax-officers-retires-33-more-116050600022_1.html|title=For good governance, Finance Ministry fires 72 tax officers, retires 33 more|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=[[Business Standard]]}}</ref><ref name="PIB">{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=144910|title=Government takes strict action against defaulting/non performing tax officials/officers|accessdate=12 May 2016|publisher=[[Press Information Bureau]]}}</ref>
Though the government has removed group A civil servants in the past also, this is the first time, when the members of this power lobby of "Group A Civil Servants" have been removed in such a large number

==Miscellaneous==
===Civil Service Day=== The Civil Service Day is celebrated on 21 April every year.<ref name="Day Civil Service">{{cite web|url=http://darpg.gov.in/ArticleContent.aspx?category=116 |title=Civil Services Day|date=8 June 2011 |work= |publisher=Department of Administrative Reforms & Public Grievances, [[Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions (India)|Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions]]|location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref> The purpose for this day is to rededicate and recommit themselves to the cause of the people. It is observed by all Civil Services. This day gives civil servants the opportunity for introspection and thinking about future strategies to deal with the challenges being posed by the changing times.<ref name="PM Award Excellence">{{cite web |url=http://darpg.gov.in/darpgwebsite_cms/Document/file/pmaward_scheme_eng.pdf |title=The Prime Minister’s Awards for Excellence in Public Administration Award Scheme|date=8 June 2011 |work= |publisher=Department of Administrative Reforms & Public Grievances, [[Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions (India)|Ministry of Personnel, Public Grievances and Pensions]]|location=[[New Delhi]] |accessdate=14 Feb 2012}}</ref>
On this occasion, all officers of Central and State Governments are honoured for excellence in public administration by the [[Prime Minister of India]]. The 'Prime Minister Award for Excellence in Public Administration' is presented in three categories. Under this scheme of awards instituted in 2006, all the officers individually or as group or as organisation are eligible.<ref name=" PM Award Excellence"/>
The award includes a medal, scroll and a cash amount of {{INRConvert|100000}}. In case of a group, the total award money is {{INRConvert|500000}} subject to a maximum of {{INRConvert|100000}} per person. For an organisation the cash amount is limited to {{INRConvert|500000}}.<ref name=" PM Award Excellence"/>
